Hi @yutongzhang-microsoft ,
After the changes you made to `remove_topo.yml` and `destroy_vm_network.yml`,
running `remove_topo` fails with the following error:

fatal: [*****]: FAILED! => {"reason": "Could not find or access '/root/mars/workspace/sonic-mgmt/ansible/destory_vm_network.yml' on the Ansible Controller."}

The directory path is incorrect. After fixing the directory, another error occurs because `destroy_vm_network.yml` uses `throttle: 1`, which is not a valid attribute:

](fatal: [*****]: FAILED! => {"reason": "'throttle' is not a valid attribute for a Task

The error appears to be in '/root/mars/workspace/sonic-mgmt/ansible/roles/vm_set/tasks/destroy_vm_network.yml': line 1, column 3, but may
be elsewhere in the file depending on the exact syntax problem.

The offending line appears to be:


- name: Destroy VMs network {{ vm_name }}
 ^ here
We could be wrong, but this one looks like it might be an issue with
missing quotes. Always quote template expression brackets when they
start a value. For instance:

 with_items:
 - {{ foo }}

Should be written as:

 with_items:
 - "{{ foo }}"

This error can be suppressed as a warning using the "invalid_task_attribute_failed" configuration"})

After correcting these two issues (fixing the directory path and removing the invalid `throttle` attribute), `remove_topo` runs successfully.

Hi, @gshemesh2 , I noticed the first issue was a typo, which has already been fixed in PR #19334. I believe the second error was also caused by the same problem, as I've tested it multiple times in my local environment without encountering any failures. Thanks for bringing it to my attention.

> Hi, @gshemesh2 , I noticed the first issue was a typo, which has already been fixed in PR #19334. I believe the second error was also caused by the same problem, as I've tested it multiple times in my local environment without encountering any failures. Thanks for bringing it to my attention.

throttle controls how many hosts can run tasks simultaneously
The throttle keyword is a playbook-level or block-level keyword, not a task-level keyword on all ansible versions:
In Ansible 2.8.20, throttle is available as a playbook-level parameter, but not at the task level.

Triaged the same bug and came to a similar conclusion. This fix would definitely solve the issue.

However I'm not sure if it would be better to explicitly check each DUT for a suitable portchannel/interface in case there is a future chassis T2 topology where it could possibly reach a 2nd suitable DUT.

e.g. 1st DUT doesn't have a suitable portA, but 2nd DUT does

For example, replacing old L234-239:

```
 # Check if at least one port of type port_type_a exists in the downlink (T1/LT2 neighbors)
 port_type_a_intf_exists = False
 for _, intfs in list(portT1_neigh.items()):
 for intf in intfs:
 port_type_a_intf_exists = (port_type_a == "ethernet" and intf.startswith("Ethernet")) or \
 (port_type_a == "portchannel" and intf.startswith("PortChannel"))
 if port_type_a_intf_exists:
 break

 if dutA and port_type_a_intf_exists:
 break
 elif dutA:
 logger.info("Found DUT {} with downlink (T1/LT2) neighbors, but contains no ports of type {}"
 .format(dutA, port_type_a))
 dutA = None

 if dutA is None:
 pytest.skip("Did not find any asic in the DUTs (linecards) "
 "that are connected to downlink (T1/LT2) VM's OR "
 "did not find any downlink (T1/LT2) ports of type {}".format(port_type_a))
```

looks to specific issue when there are only 2 ports available for testing.

To exemplify the problem a little more: Consider a situation where Et1 and Et2 are the only test ports available.

Et1's rx port is Et2 and vice versa. So when a storm is started on Et1 it will start to drop traffic and PTF will no longer see the traffic it sends to Et2 coming back through from Et1. 
The SendVerifyTraffic class first ensures that traffic sent to Et2 is being properly egressed from the dut back to PTF but at this point it would assume that Et2 is not functioning correctly since a storm is already started cauing the traffic to drop.

@congh-nvidia Can you help me understand `When the erspan version is IPv6 and the topo is t0, there will be a storm in the vlan when the test packet is sent to the dut.` ?

> @congh-nvidia Can you help me understand `When the erspan version is IPv6 and the topo is t0, there will be a storm in the vlan when the test packet is sent to the dut.` ?

Hi @bingwang-ms, the reason is:

The test packet is mirrored and encapsulated with IPv6
The encap packet is send to ptf.
Ptf received the packet and tries to forward(the dst mac is ptf mac, and ptf has the ipv6 route ), so it sends ipv6 NS to all ptf interfaces(including those in the vlan) to resolve the neighbor.
The IPv6 NS is received by the dut, and it is mirrored and sent to the ptf with the same ipv6 encap, and then trigger the IPv6 NS again, which causes the storm.

The change logic looks good to me. One minor suggestion, why not put the commands into a bash script and run the script instead of running it in batches? If there are too many ip addr in the list, that can result in multiple SSH and multiple calls.

> The change logic looks good to me. One minor suggestion, why not put the commands into a bash script and run the script instead of running it in batches? If there are too many ip addr in the list, that can result in multiple SSH and multiple calls.

Is your suggestion to create a file with the batched up commands on the duthost first and then make one call to `shell` to execute that file? I figured this would be overkill as more than likely this will only execute the `shell` command 1-4 times.

Also there is already a precedent of doing it this way here: https://github.com/sonic-net/sonic-mgmt/pull/8126

Hello,

This test case fails if it gonna be enabled for multi-asic.

The test case is suppossed to change the Loopback interface under /localhost namespace.
Patch that is applied successfully:
`[{"op": "remove", "path": "/LOOPBACK_INTERFACE/Loopback0|10.1.0.1~132"}, {"op": "remove", "path": "/LOOPBACK_INTERFACE/Loopback0|FC00:10::1~1128"}, {"op": "add", "path": "/LOOPBACK_INTERFACE/Loopback0|10.1.0.210~132", "value": {}}, {"op": "add", "path": "/LOOPBACK_INTERFACE/Loopback0|FC00:1::210~1128", "value": {}}]`

After that change running database has these values:

```
$ sonic-cfggen -d -v LOOPBACK_INTERFACE
{'Loopback0': {}, ('Loopback0', '10.1.0.210/32'): {}, ('Loopback0', 'FC00:1::210/128'): {}}
```

```
$ sonic-cfggen -n asic0 -d -v LOOPBACK_INTERFACE
{'Loopback0': {}, ('Loopback0', '10.1.0.1/32'): {}, ('Loopback0', 'FC00:10::1/128'): {}, 'Loopback4096': {}, ('Loopback4096', '2603:10e2:400::1/128'): {}, ('Loopback4096', '8.0.0.1/32'): {}}
```

```
$ sonic-cfggen -n asic1 -d -v LOOPBACK_INTERFACE
{'Loopback0': {}, ('Loopback0', '10.1.0.1/32'): {}, ('Loopback0', 'FC00:10::1/128'): {}, 'Loopback4096': {}, ('Loopback4096', '2603:10e2:400::2/128'): {}, ('Loopback4096', '8.0.0.2/32'): {}}
```

As you can see there is an incosistency for Loopback0 between /localhost and asic namespaces.

The test verifies based on `"show ip int"` command and doesnt' find the updated expected value and fails.

```
$ show ip int
Interface Master IPv4 address/mask Admin/Oper BGP Neighbor Neighbor IP
-------------- -------- ------------------- ------------ -------------- -------------
Loopback0 10.1.0.1/32 up/up N/A N/A
```

Which means the cli command "show ip int" fetches values based on namespaces cfg?

I am not sure what is the expected here.

We can modify the patch to apply change in localhost as well as in all asic namespaces in case of multiasci duthost and that will pass the case, 
but my question is , is the output of "show ip int" expected in above scenario?


Thanks,
Olympia
